title: When will the yield curve for 2-year and 10-year U.S. Treasurys next invert?
preds: It's July 30 and it's not inverted.
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.

The base rate for a yield-curve inversion is pretty low - https://www.globalfinancialdata.com/the-inverted-yield-curve-in-historical-perspective/ A comparison between the current yield curve vs yield curves from 1m/6m back is here - http://www.worldgovernmentbonds.com/country/united-states/
We can see in the link that 'normal convexity' has been maintained during the last 6 months, and in fact the longer term maturities (7 years and above) part of the curve have seen increased yields in the last 1 month.  So low chances of an inversion before 1st August 2020.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-06-16/harvard-s-rogoff-negative-rates-should-be-on-the-table-for-fed-video Negative rates come into play, and I am very curious how much faster the 10y rate will sink than the 2y rate, and whether the short term rates will experience any "singularity effects" from the situation being without a blue print, and from possible rating changes.
Fed is propping markets and giving a long timeline on 0 rates.
Last happened August 2019. Do not see it before August 1. Could happen if a fall lockdown results from upsurge in covid-19.

Ok 90/10. This inversion is a harbinger of a recession. With lifting lock-down things should pick-up some and it may take awhile before a collapse. It is September with a second surge that should be s worry.
Less likely as economy opens up.
Decide my first impression as harbinger of recession is good so perhaps put some in other bins.

https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/treasuries-longer-term-yields-fall-on-growing-worries-of-pandemics-impact-2020-04-01
10 year dropping despite Fed. In short term probably not but as effect on economy going forward with everything stuck in neutral and massive unemployment it might. This is a classic harbinger of a recession.
The Fed wins and can tune as it sees fit. In good hands.
The FED as the buyer of last resort, with unlimited firepower, can tune the market.
The bond market will be artificial for the foreseeable future, and not driven by market forces. The Fed will be buying enough treasuries to set rates.
March 23 steep drop in both rates as congress fiddles and cities burn with new cases   2yr=0.28 and 10yr=0.76
With rates at zero and the Fed buying across maturities, you would need a serious flight to quality to push the 10-year below the 2

March 20 = 0.37%  and 0.92% a quick drop in both 2 and 10yr as well as 20yr and 30yr as Fed applies more tools. We are taking on water as the Fed tries to get the ship into harbor before the storm comes.
The stimulus package appears to be staving that off. .38 for two year and 10 year 1.06.
March 18 = 0.54 vs. 1.18. The short term is now pegged firmly near zero. 4-1/2 months to go, lots could happen.

Geez...things are all over the place. Both yields are dropping. An inversion denotes a recession and we may be headed that way. https://www.kitco.com/news/2020-03-12/Here-s-how-gold-silver-ratio-can-predict-the-future-much-more-pain-ahead-of-us.html

Making some slight adjustments. The things that worry me most are not the “normal” causes of an inversion (i.e. Fed is tightening which raises the 2 year while buying in the 10 year and lower inflation expectations push that yield down)). Rather liquidity in the off-the-run market, algorithmic trading shocks, low dealer stock, volatility hedging, and trade unwinding which Could all cause an abnormal shift in the curve keeps me nervous. With that being said, the Fed has agreed to offer liquidity to ensure smooth funding and is buying Treasuries along the curve. That should be sufficient to keep it steep for the time-being. The real question becomes what happens when the short-rate is at the ZLB?

I was wrong. The two year yield is dropping fast. If the 10 year yield is less than the two year yield then that is an inversion. If that happens it is a sign of recession. That could happen but we are not there yet.

It marks a recession. The coronavirus is going to have an impact on the heavily service weighted economy. Stocks already showing it but give the bond inversion a couple weeks as the spread of infection becomes clearer. Most people have mild symptoms but the measures to keep it under control will have an effect. Reuters March 9: The two-year, 10-year yield curve US2US10=TWEB, which is also closely watched as a recession indicator, flattened as far as 2 basis points, before steepening back to 13 basis points. 
Assume this is end of day measurement not instantaneous.

26 bp margin, steep corona margin widening will take time to phase out. Global CB (easing) policy should depress rates.

Good analysis below. If any one of us (or all of us) crack predicting the yield inversion, it'll make someone quite rich. I recall last August and standing there flinching like someone waiting for a punch to the face. That said, and at the risk of sounding stupider than I already am, if it is going to happen, I feel it'll happen sooner (COVID-19) or later (downstream supply-chain ramifications of COVID-19.)

The yield curve inverted last august. The curve afterwards went back to (small) positive, Usually when the curve moves from negative to positive it takes a while for the curve to invert again. Especially if the marktet is on recession watch like today and the 2yr rate reflecting 2-3 rate cuts before the summer (the 2yr rate is a very good indication for the Fed rate 3 months later). As the effecst of the Coronavirus are likely to fade with time the added stimulus will lead to a better grothw outlook with higher inflation expectations leading to a steepening curve.

When will the yield curve for 2-year and 10-year U.S. Treasurys next invert?
Hattip @ikresnak for a very complete well reasoned arguement which forces me to alter my forecast.

Yield curve inversions are predictive of recessions because investors think rates in the future will be lower than current rates and buy longer-dated bonds while selling shorter dated bonds. This is largely due to the fact that interest rates on the 10-yr reflect future expectations for inflation. If growth and inflation are expected to slow (a recession), then the 10-yr falls. Meanwhile, if the Fed is still hiking rates, the 2-yr rises and the curve inverts. Structural factors keeping inflation low have prevented this from occurring. now to the elephant in the room - coronavirus and it's impact on bond yields. When looking at the yield curve since January (https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/interest-rates/Pages/TextView.aspx?data=yieldYear&year=2020) yields have certainly plummeted, but the move seems to be mostly parallel with the 2-10 spread not changing much. Rabobank did a study in 2016 where they looked at different factors that affect the yield curve (https://services.rabobank.com/publicationservice/download/publication/token/A90yi2feIba60IkcVftD) - particularly the 2-10 spread. They looked at 4 variables (Fed Funds Rate, VIX, Non-farm Payrolls, and CPI) and found that changes in the Fed Funds rate affect the 2-yr more than the 10-yr (higher beta). They also found that inflation affects the 10-yr more than the 2-yr. Impact of NFP was small and the VIX put slightly more downward pressure on the 2 year than the 10 year. In the context of this forecast, this would suggest the following:
1. IF the Fed cuts rates, the 2 year will fall more than the 10 year 
2. IF inflation (CPI) falls, the 10 year will decline more than the 2 year
3. IF the VIX stays elevated the 2 year will fall more than the 10 year
4. The 2 year is more sensitive to NFP than the 10 year My expectation is for the coronavirus to serve primarily as a demand shock in the US. While the supply-chain argument certainly resonates and could be inflationary (factories can't complete and ship goods so prices rise), the US economy is more service-based and demand for many of those services will be down if H-2-H interaction is considered risky. This lack of demand will push prices down and, along with lower energy prices, contribute to lower inflation. Job growth will also likely slow if cases continue to grow in the US. While higher job growth has not proven to raise inflation, I think declining job growth will push it down further. Going back to the Rabobank study, the biggest drivers of an inversion would be either the Fed not cutting, CPI falling, or a combination of the two. The market is already pricing in aggressive Fed action (https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html) and while inflation might not materially pick up, the energy component of CPI should rebound. Before 5/1, the situation will either dramatically improve or the Fed will act. After that, warmer weather should send coronavirus the same way as the seasonal flu (https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2020/02/12/805256402/can-coronavirus-be-crushed-by-warmer-weather) and the "cautious reflation" narrative resumes as the world realizes nothing is materially different but macro risks related to trade and policy still persist
Hattip @noob22 for analysis, but I'll bias toward sooner rather than later. Last year's inversion happened within a month of our most recent similar chart pattern. Fear is a great motivator.

As of now - 
i) higher probability to invert during next few weeks vs later months as investors seek safety in longer term bonds during pandemic panic -> supply (chain) and demand shocks
ii) expectation that rates will be lower in future - CBs begin easing as result of market correction/s
iii) assume that covid2019 panic selling begins easing between may and july (estimated for now - may need correcting) and probabiltiy of reversion declines but does not dissapear
iv) still highest chance of reversion post August 2020 (esp if reversion indicitive of recession which at some stage 'must' happen.
